title: Skilled Workers Oppose Utility Tariffs Increase
text:
8 September 2015 13:51 CET Skilled Workers Oppose Utility Tariffs Increase By Daily Guide 
Some seamstresses at work Skilled workers in the Eastern Region have rejected the proposed increase in utility tariffs by the utility providers. 
Speaking at a consultative forum organized by the Public Utilities Regulatory Commission (PURC) in Koforidua, many tailors, dressmakers, hairdressers and small-scale investors, who spoke at the forum, were of the opinion that any increase in utility tariffs would seriously affect their work and force them to close down their businesses. 
They argued that already they were saddled with high taxes from the Ghana Revenue Authority (GRA) and the district assemblies, which is eroding their earnings. 
They claimed they have workers to pay and also take care of many apprentices from deprived rural communities, whose parents cannot feed them. 
The skilled workers claimed their situation had been aggravated by the economic crisis in the country. 
Workers who come to sew dresses refuse to come for them because they have no money to pay and even ladies, who come to style their hair, fail to honour promises of paying back the monies, they said. 
The Eastern Regional Secretary of the Trade Union Congress (TUC), Phyllis Agyemang called on the utility service providers to reduce waste and stop passing on their inefficiency onto consumers. 
She said workers have not received any salary increase and so cannot afford any increase in utility tariffs. 
Mrs Agyemang said workers and employers were facing a lot of challenges due to the power outages and therefore any increase in electricity bills at this time would be wrong. 
Other participants at the forum complained about numerous problems in relation to the acquisition of electricity and water services. 
Daniel Owusu Koranteng, a member of the PURC, who chaired the function, said the reactions of the participants at the forum had given the Commission a lot to seriously think about. 
Volta River Authority (VRA), representing power generators, is demanding a 100 percent increase in rates, while GRIDCo is demanding 25 percent increase. 
Electricity Company of Ghana is demanding over 100 percent increase and the Ghana Water Company is demanding an increase of its basic rate from GH¢1.70 per a unit of water to GH¢4.00. 
GNA
